elements.text: hello all, anybody still in this channel?  I have some confusion about online solvers
Yeah we're around! What's up?

text: does `simulate` re-initialize solvers on every call?  I'm running the MCTS solver and looking at the tree state I feel like it is doing that (though I haven't completely figured out how to read the tree state yet)

elements.text: does
simulate
re-initialize solvers on every call?  I'm running the MCTS solver and looking at the tree state I feel like it is doing that (though I haven't completely figured out how to read the tree state yet)

text: I guess a better question is, what's the recommended way to train online solvers?  is it with `simulate`?

text: actually maybe I'm misunderstanding how this whole thing works.  I suppose maybe the MCTS just assumes that the state space is so large that every encounter is new, and it just has to create an entirely new tree at every step no matter what

elements.text: actually maybe I'm misunderstanding how this whole thing works.  I suppose maybe the MCTS just assumes that the state space is so large that every encounter is new, and it just has to create an entirely new tree at every step no matter what

text: that seems to be what's going on

elements.text: that seems to be what's going on

text: yup, ok so this was a stupid question.  my initial thinking was that because many MDP's have a specific starting state (e.g. most games) that this thing would have some sort of hysteresis

elements.text: yup, ok so this was a stupid question.  my initial thinking was that because many MDP's have a specific starting state (e.g. most games) that this thing would have some sort of hysteresis

text: There might be an option to reuse the tree when you initialize MCTS

elements.text: There might be an option to reuse the tree when you initialize MCTS

text:
```reuse_tree::Bool:
        If this is true, the tree information is re-used for calculating the next plan.
        Of course, clear_tree! can always be called to override this.
        default: false```

elements.text:
reuse_tree::Bool:
        If this is true, the tree information is re-used for calculating the next plan.
        Of course, clear_tree! can always be called to override this.
        default: false

text: I do not remember exactly how it is implemented though, whether it just saves compute time, or whether it adds new information (saved tree + what you would have computed at this time).

elements.text: I do not remember exactly how it is implemented though, whether it just saves compute time, or whether it adds new information (saved tree + what you would have computed at this time).

text: it's pretty cool that the ability to do that is built in though... this looks almost flesible that you could plug Flux into it and do an AlphaGo

elements.text: it's pretty cool that the ability to do that is built in though... this looks almost flesible that you could plug Flux into it and do an AlphaGo

text:
There is an example notebook on setting Q and N, the `estimate_value` parameter is also very useful :slightly_smiling_face:
There is an AlphaZero.jl package as well but it is not part of the POMDPs.jl ecosystem.
